meanings.definition: A loud, resonant sound or noise, especially that made by metal objects striking together.
meanings.sent1: The clangor of the church bells filled the air with a joyful noise.
meanings.sent2: The sudden clangor of pots and pans clattering to the ground startled everyone in the kitchen.
meanings.sent3: The clangor of the wind chimes outside was so loud that it drowned out the music playing inside the house.
meanings.sent4: Amidst the clangor of construction work, the chirping of birds seemed like a distant memory.
meanings.sent5: The clangor of the blacksmith's hammer against the anvil echoed through the village, signaling the start of a new day.

meanings.definition: A continuous loud banging or ringing sound.
meanings.sent1: The constant clangor of the fire alarm made it hard to concentrate on anything else.
meanings.sent2: The clangor of the old grandfather clock could be heard throughout the entire house.
meanings.sent3: Despite the clangor of the traffic outside, she managed to fall asleep within minutes.
meanings.sent4: The clangor of the metal gate swinging back and forth in the wind kept the neighborhood awake all night.
meanings.sent5: The clangor of the school bell signaled the end of another long day of classes.

meanings.definition: To make a loud, harsh, metallic sound.
meanings.sent1: The blacksmith would clangor the metal against the anvil to shape it into a sword.
meanings.sent2: As the storm approached, the wind began to clangor against the windows of the house.
meanings.sent3: The old car would clangor loudly every time it hit a bump in the road.
meanings.sent4: The cymbals would clangor together in perfect harmony during the orchestra's performance.
meanings.sent5: The pots and pans would clangor noisily as she dropped them into the sink after dinner.
